_prev_prog_3.MD_OtherType: Use manual detection device to determine severity of release

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
OSHA's Process Safety Management Standard (PSM), Title 29 Code of Federal Regulations 1910.119, and EPA's Risk Management Program regulations (RMP), Title 40 CFR Part 68. In addition to other state and local codes applicable to our facility and process. We have undertaken this process to deal with the risks involved with the storage, handling, and use of Anhydrous Ammonia in our facility.

Superior Dairy Inc. is a family owned processor and distributor of dairy products. Our plant is located in an industrial setting with several small housing developments in close proximity. The plant has been located at this site for approximately 78 years and has grown from a small residential-type structure to its present 


DESCRIPTION OF THE PROCESS SAFETY AND THE REFRIGERATION SYSTEM

Superior Dairy receives its raw milk supply from a variety of small, independent farms in the surrounding communities. This milk is processed and packaged into various products which are sold to a number of different outlets. Our product line includes items such as milk, cottage cheese, sour cream, dip, fruit juices, and drinks as well as a variety of frozen dessert items like ice cream and stick novelties. These products are briefly held in storage at our facility before being shipped to warehouses, hospitals, grocery stores, and other retail outlets.

These processing and storage functions require the use of some working fluid to be used as a refrigerant in our refrigeration system. The primary refrigerant used at Superior Dairy is anhydrous ammonia. This refrigerant is used mainly because of its efficient cooling capabilities. Ammonia also has several other key advantages over other refrigerants such as CFC's, HCFC's and HFC's:

1. Ammonia is lighter than air and will thus dissipate more quickly than other refrigerants in the event of a release.
2. Ammonia has an extremely pungent odor which gives it an excellent alarming quality.
3. From a volumetric standpoint, much less ammonia

is required to achieve the same cooling results as other available mediums.
4. Ammonia released to the atmosphere has no negative effect on the ozone level in contrast to
CFC's.

The above listed advantages make ammonia the clear choice for both health and environmental
considerations.

In the daily operations at Superior, a wide variety of chemicals are used to clean and sanitize processing and packaging equipment. This chemical use is necessary to ensure that our products are of the highest quality. Because of the chemical usage in our plant, Superior places a very high priority on safe chemical handling practices. Employees are regularly trained by both our own people as well as a variety of individuals from outside sources. Regular audits and inspections are conducted by our supervisors in conjunction with our chemical suppliers to uncover any deficiencies in our chemical handling procedures.

In accordance with 40 CFR part 68, EPA's Risk Management Program, Superior Dairy has conducted an offsite consequence analysis to determine the impact of an ammonia release to the surrounding area. Our analysis was conducted using information about our facility to determine the toxic endpoints with the aid of ALOHA-MARPLOT software and the 2010 Census Data.

Superior Dairy is also required to comply with OSHA's Process Safety Management Program. In complying with these programs, Superior has made a concerted effort to continuously improve the ammonia refrigeration system in use at our plant. Through the implementation of programs like Process Hazard Analysis, written operating procedures, hot work permitting, employee participation, and management of change procedures, we are constantly striving to reduce or eliminate any risk associated with the use of ammonia. The additional process of compiling safety information and using this information to train our employees has increased the knowledge and general safety awareness of our employees. This same safety infor

mation is used to train contract employees about the hazards associated with an ammonia release. By training our contractors and reviewing their safety programs before they begin any work in our plant, we hope to reduce the possibility of an accident involving an outside employee.


SUMMARY OF THE FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

Our five year accident history is truly remarkable. Superior Dairy has never in its history experienced a reportable release. Also no employee or contractor has ever suffered a serious injury associated with an ammonia release. This outstanding record is a testament to the seriousness with which we at Superior treat our ammonia system and its safe operation.


DESCRIPTION OF THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN

Our emergency response system is coordinated with the Stark County LEPC. In the unlikely event of a reportable release, the Perry Township Fire Department as the initial point of contact would make the determination as to when the HAZMAT team should be called into action. The LEPC in coordination with Perry Township would then determine what, if any, public evacuation should follow. Superior Dairy has taken the additional precaution of contracting with Sunohio to handle any clean up required by a release. Sunohio is also trained to respond should something prevent the HAZMAT team from responding to an emergency. This additional precaution has been taken as insurance against any personal or environmental injury.

Safety is a primary concern of everyone at Superior Dairy. Management is actively involved in the safety programs at Superior and the goal is to constantly look for opportunities to improve our programs. Superior management has been and will continue to be a strong advocate for providing a safe work environment for our employees. We are also committed to remaining a responsible corporate citizen and a qood neiqhbor to the community.
